lines.text: [as Libby works in the prison kitchen, Margaret gives Libby some legal advice for when she's released from prison]
Pay attention, because this is the best goddamn advice you're ever gonna get. Ever hear of something called double jeopardy? Fifth Amendment to the constitution?

[Libby shakes her head left to right]
Huh? No? Well, double jeopardy provides that 'no person may be tried for the same crime twice.' You got that? Keep stirrin'. The state says you already killed your husband. They can't convict you of it a second time. That means that when you leave here, and you track him down, and when you find him you can kill him. That's right. You can walk right up to him in Times Square, put a gun to his head and pull the fuckin' trigger, and there's nothin' anybody can do about it.

[Libby makes a slight smile]
Kinda makes you feel warm and tingly all over, don't it? That's right. keep stirrin'.
[Nick threatens Libby as Libby threatens him with the law of double jeopardy]
They're tough in Louisiana, Libby. You shoot me, they'll give you the gas chamber.
No they won't. It's called double jeopardy. I learned a few things in prison, Nick. I could shoot you in the middle of Mardi Gras and they can't touch me.
As an ex-law professor, I can assure you she is right.
[Libby shoots the painting behind Nick's head]

[Libby smiles]
I haven't felt that good in six years. I don't want to kill you, Nick. I just want you to suffer like I suffered.
What she means, Nick, is, you're going to prison - For murder.
Who did I supposedly murder?
Me.
All you've got is an old fax photo.
Which supplies the motive. Your wife, whom you had framed, tracks you down, and to keep her from exposing you, you kill her.
[Libby talks to the boutique saleswoman under a false hotel name]
I'm sorry. Are you... lost?
No. Actually, I'm found. I just had an hour with Jerome.
Oh. Jerome. I've heard that he is marvelous.
He's fabulous. I haven't felt this good since the day my husband died.
[Libby talks to Travis outside of the ambulance]
I guess I'm gonna take off now.
No. No, you're not. You're a parole violator. You're in my c-custody. You're going with me to Seattle, where I will demand a full pardon and a parade... and a little pink poodle... on a keychain.
[the two laugh and smile]
[the handsome internet expert tries to ask Libby out for a drink]
Now, maybe when this thing has finished its searching, we could go to this, uh, this neat little bar I know and, uh, have a little drink. What do you say?

[Libby smiles and agrees]
Yeah. I just have to check in with my parole officer first.
You've been to jail?
Actually, prison. Jail is a different thing.

[the kid nervously laughs]
So, what did you do, not pay your parking tickets?
Oh, no. I was convicted of murdering my husband.
You're kidding, right?
No, I'm not. Um, 'Sliced and Diced,' the paper called it. Can you believe that?
[Evelyn watches Libby jog in the rain within the prison fences]

[Evelyn shouts]
I got to hand it to you, honey. It's just sheer hate driving you on.
[Libby walks to Nick holding a pistol at him, as Nick talks to Travis who's watching from the chair]
Well, aren't you gonna do something?
What are you talkin' to me for? She's the one with the gun.
[Travis asks Jim Mangold for his assistance in finding Libby in New Orleans]

[Travis shows Jim a prison photo of Libby]
Pretty girl.
Oh, yeah. She's very pretty, for a convicted murderer. She jumped parole on me.
Mr. Lehman, I'd love to be able to help you, sir.
No, I don't want you guys to go to any trouble. I can handle matters. I just came down as a professional courtesy, since she's in New Orleans, and came here to kill one of your prominent citizens.
And just how is she planning on doing that?
I don't know. She'll probably use the .38 Special she stole from me.
[Libby takes advice from Margaret and Evelyn on what to tell the parole board]
I feel like I've grown these past six years.
'Grown'? Honey, they don't want to hear that you've turned into some kind of tree, okay? So you just repeat after me, 'If I could trade places with my husband, I would.'

[Libby rolls her eyes]
Ugh. 'If I could trade places with my husband, I would.'
That's good. Now, throw in a lot of that born-again-Jesus stuff. They like that.
[Libby meets the female inmates Margaret and Evelyn]
Who's this?
Rich-bitch from Whidbey island. She ain't gonna make it.
What do you think, a year?
Five cartons says she offs herself inside of six months.
Deal.
Get away from me.
Hey, take it easy. We're your new best friends.
Heard you did your husband. He probably deserved it.
Mine did.
[Margaret and Evelyn walk off smiling]
[Libby goes next door to the neighbor's house of Angela Green's former residence]
Excuse me?
Dear, whatever you're selling, I've already got two of them.
[Libby and Travis talk on the drive to the boat after Libby's parole violation]
Okay. I killed my husband. I chopped him up into little bits, and I dumped him piece by piece into the Pacific. Are you satisfied?
No. No. You were a hell of a lot closer to your kid three days ago than you are today. All you had to do was wait three years. That's all. You fucking idiot!

You cannot know what it is like to sit in prison for six years and think of nothing else in the world but your son. Did I make the right choice? You asked the wrong question, Lehman, I didn't have a choice. Fuck your curfew!

[Libby sees a picture of a girl on Lehman's sun visor]
Who's that? Your daughter?

[Travis closes the visor without responding]
Is that a problem for you, Lehman?
[last lines]

[Libby finds Matty at his school as he plays Soccer in the field, Libby calls out to him at the end of the half]
Matty.

[Matty hears her voice]
Matty.

[Matty walks up to her]
Hi. Do you know who I am?

[Matty nods up and down]
They told me you were dead.

[Libby smiles]
No, sweetheart.
[Libby combs her hand to Matty's face and hugs him]
[Libby asks her attorney and friend, if he thinks she murdered her husband]
Do you think I killed him?
That's the first rule of being a lawyer. What we think doesn't matter.
It matters to me.

[Cutter lights his cigarette and pauses]
No. Of course. I don't think you killed him.
[Libby sees Travis kick one of the other girls out of the house]

[Travis looks to Libby]
You think I'm a mean son of a bitch?
I think you could have given her a second chance.
There are no second chances in this house, baby. This is the last chance house! You try to understand that.
[Libby nervously talks to Travis outside of Matty's school]
I don't know if I've ever been so scared in my whole life. I think a big part of me never thought I'd really find him. What if he doesn't recognize me? I mean, maybe after all this time...
Dammit, woman! Because of you, I have lost a perfectly good used car, and a not-so-good job. If you don't go to this kid right now, I'm gonna have you arrested for stupidity. Go on.

[Libby smiles]
Thanks, Lehman. You saved my life.
You saved mine, too.
[Travis visits Jonathan Devereaux one last time at his hotel]
Mr. Devereaux?
Mr. Lehman. I'm sorry. This is really not a good time.
I understand. A lot of people feel that way about me. But I have good news.

[Jonathan pauses]
It won't take long.
[first lines]

[Libby fishs with her son Matty]
I'm pretty hungry. Hope we catch some fish soon.
Me, too.

[Libby winds the fishing line back in]
Okay, help me wind.
Wind back?
Can we turn this one? Slowly. Slowly, slowly, slowly, slowly.
I am doing it slowly.

[Libby smiles]
Okay, you got it.
[Libby talks to Matty about wanting to teach him to sail]
Oh, Matty, look! You see that? See that big boat out there?
Mm-hmm.
She is the prettiest boat on Whidbey Island. That's the Morning Star. Someday when you're big enough I'm gonna teach you how to sail. It's the best thing there is, sailing.
Better than fishing?
Yup. But you know what, kiddo? I don't think I want you to grow up.
Why?
What if you grow up and marry some beautiful girl? Who's gonna go sailing with me then?
Dad.
Not a chance.
[a yuppie man tries to impress his date while at Nick and Libby's house party]

[a yuppie man looks closer on the Parsons wall]
Hmm, yes. Picasso. Blue period.

[Nick walks into the conversation]
The artist's name is Kandinsky. Wassily Kandinsky. He was German, of Russian extraction, 1866 to 1944. And by the way, Picasso's blue period was figurative, and ended in 1904. And these watercolors are abstract, done in 1911.

[Nick leaves the conversation, as the yuppie man scoffs looking back to his date]
Picasso.
[Libby joins Nick out on the patio]
What are you thinking about?
Was I always as rude as I am now?

[Libby chuckles]
Absolutely.
[as the two kiss each other]
[Angela and Nick surprise Libby with a rental boat for the weekend]
Now, Libby, what is your favorite thing?
Me?
Not even close.

[Nick makes a frown]
All right, open.

[Libby opens her eyes to see a sail boat on the water]
I heard Sean Gittman was thinking of selling. So I made him an offer, and he agreed to let us take her out for the weekend. And if you like it, it's yours.
If I like it?
[Libby chuckles]
[Libby sails the boat as Nick joins her on the deck, noticing that they're in the middle of the ocean]
Wait. I don't see land. So where is it?

[Libby points with her hand]
Alaska's over that way, Japan is straight ahead, and Australia's somewhere to the left. Where would you like to go?
Bed.
That can be arranged.
[the prosecutor in Libby's court case tries to come up with an explanation for Nick's murder]
Mrs. Parsons, you've heard the testimony be presented to this court, and your explanation is that somebody must have come aboard the Morning Star.
That's right.
Well, let's consider all the possibilities. Maybe a band of pirates. Or aliens! Did aliens murder your husband? No. Aliens weren't beneficiaries in your husband's life insurance.
[Libby sits on the stand and pleads to the court]

[Libby with tears in her eyes]
I didn't kill my husband! I loved my husband.

[Libby hysterically sobs]
Bobby, I did not kill my husband! You have to believe me!
[Libby says goodbye to Matty before going to prison]

[Libby holds Matty in her lap]
Hey, kiddo. Come see me. You're gonna go stay with Angie for a while. Okay, kiddo?
Okay.
You're gonna have lots of fun, and I know you're gonna be a good boy, right?
Yes, Mommy.
And as soon as this is all over, we'll be together again. That's a promise, kiddo. Okay? I love you.

[Libby holds Matty to her chest kissing his forehead repeatedly]
I love you, too.
[Evelyn and Margaret give Libby some encouragement to find her son]
Heard you're tryin' to reach your friend, the one with your boy.
Yeah, I can't find 'em. They disappeared.
Oh, hon - If you could disappear that easy, believe you me, I wouldn't be here right now.

[Evelyn chuckles]
Me, either.
Think. Use your head. There's gotta be a way to track him down.
[Libby stirs a giant pot in the kitchen prison]
Put some elbow grease behind that stirring. Nobody wants to eat any burnt tapioca.
Does it smell like it's burning?
Oh, I swear you got shit for brains, girl.
[Evelyn and the other inmates bring Libby a birthday cake for her son Matty's birthday, as Libby makes a wish and blows out the candles]
You know, Evelyn, I read that even if a child is separated from its mother the day it's born, it never forgets her voice. Think that's true?

[Evelyn smiles]
'Course I do.
[Libby meets Travis with her box of personal belongings]

[Travis holds up a photo of Libby's son, Matty]
Is this a problem for you?
No.
Yes, it is. Do you want to tell me about him?

[scoffs]
No.

[Travis drops the photo back into her box]
I'm gonna have trouble with you, Parsons.
No, sir. No, you're not. I learned my lesson. I just want to...
I'm not interested in your goddamn contrition. I'm interested in your behavior. Get out of here and behave yourself. You're in room eight on the second floor.
[the handsome internet expert helps Libby look for her friend Angela]
Now, uh, what are you looking for?
A friend I haven't seen for a couple years. People said I should try the internet.
This a boy... friend?
Girl.

[the kid smiles]
Okay. Well, in that case, I'll help you.
[Libby sits in her jail cell after being arrested for evading police on the beach]

[Travis walks into her cell]
Did you have a nice day on the beach?
[Libby visits her mother in her garden]

[Libby's mother digs out a container of cash]
I always said there was good money in tomatoes.
[handing it over to Libby]
[Travis visits one of his former parolee's to look up information on Angela Green]
What I need is a search on a lady named Angela Green. I got her social security number here. I'd like you to...
Please. You know I'm not allowed to give out personal information.
Oh, I'm sorry - I shouldn't ask you that.
Uh-huh.

[Travis begins to talk in a higher voice]
Speaking of giving out personal information does your employer know that you used to perform the art of fellatio for a living.
Okay. Okay.

[Travis continues]
Went to prison for it, and now you're out on parole.
Shut up.
You're required by law to tell him.

[Orbe takes the paper from Travis]
All right. Okay.

[Orbe begins looking up the information as Travis checks Orbe out]
You're looking good, Orbe.

[Orbe responds back]
I know.
[Travis shows up to the New Orleans police station and meets Jim Mangold]

[Jim sees Travis admiring his fish on the wall]
Did you catch that thing?

[Jim nods up and down]
What did you use for bait?
I caught that big bucket-mouth son of a bitch off an old rebel lure my daddy left me. 'Course there's buzz bombs, poppers, jigs - All kinds of things work back in these waters.
[Suzanne Monroe introduces herself to Libby at the Hotel auction]
I don't believe we've met. I'm Suzanne Monroe.
I'm Libby. I'm his wife.
Well, Jonathan! A minute ago a bachelor, and now you're married. You don't waste any time. You been in New Orleans long?
She's, uh...
I'm just passing through town to pick up my child. I'll be leaving very soon.
How nice.
We're finally putting the past behind us and moving on with our lives, aren't we, Jonathan?
Sure.
I do have one question, though. How long were you and Angie fucking before you decided to get rid of me?
[the conversation goes silent as Suzanne Monroe clears her throat]
[the New Orleans bartender talks to Libby about the Wanted posters]

[the bartender hands Libby a Wanted poster of herself]
Cops have been passing these out.

[the bartender then tears it up]
No reward. Screw 'em.
You're gonna be posted at every hotel in town.
So much for a good night's sleep.

[the bartender hands Libby an umbrella]
Take this. Get out of here.
[Travis questions Nick, who is going by the new identity Jonathan Devereaux]
Do you have any idea why she's fixated her lunacy on you?
Well, the world's full of crazy people, am I right?

[Travis laughs while responding]
Oh, yes, you are right. Truer words were never spoken.

[Travis comments on the picture behind Jonathan's desk]
Those are nice pictures there. Did your kids do them?

[Nick chuckles]
Uh, no. Those pictures are by a very great artist named Kandinsky.
Oh.
But why do I think you already knew that?
[Travis talks on the phone to his boss Karl Carruthers]
Listen to me, Karl. I think maybe this Parsons woman has been telling the truth.
You're not a law professor anymore, Travis. You're barely even a parole officer. So stop playing Mission Impossible.
All I need... is a D.M.V. driver's license photograph of Nicholas Parsons.
You get back here today... because tomorrow, you're going in front of the Commission.
Karl, I know I'm right. Give me a chance, okay? Now, I'm asking you politely...

[Travis quietly whispers before screaming out]
You send me that goddamn picture!
[Travis continues to get frustrated when he can't find the correct Nicholas Parsons' driver's license photo]
See, Lehman, the thing is, every now and again, we all want to believe in something, but we just keep forgetting that 99.9 percent of the time, life just flat don't work out.

[Travis sarcastically replies]
I hadn't thought of that, Mangold. Thanks. I feel a lot better now.
Any time, Hoss. Any time.
